Most of the experiments in this video are fairly harmless, except for the short wave ultraviolet light.

This vase has an odd behavior.

In sunlight it is violet but under
fluorescent light at night it is blue.

light bulb, that mimics sunlight

Obviously, this isn't a magical color-shifting vase
so what else is causing this color change?

You may have noticed, that even though
these two bulbs both are meant to be warm-white
they certainly don't have the same color tone.

White is not a spectral color,
but a mixture of several colors.

Let's take a closer look at what colors
these bulbs actually emit.
I have this direct vision spectroscope.
Nothing special - just a tube with a slit at one end

letting light in on a diffraction
grating at the viewing end.

This will split any incoming light
into its spectrum of colors.

Like a prism will split sunlight into
the colors of the rainbow.
Let's try the incandescent bulb first.
Sunlight is also incandescent, so it's no surprise

that we see a rainbow of all spectral
colors coming from this bulb.

Though, unlike a prism, the diffraction
grating shows the spectrum several times.

The second order spectrum is not overexposing
the camera and is more streched out
Giving us more details, so I'll focus on that one.

For some reason, the GoPro is
not recording the violet color,
but it's not that important for this video.

If we switch to the fluorescent bulb,
it's a completely different spectrum.

It's not a full spectrum from violet to red,
but a few distinct wavelengths.
When mixed together, these appear white to us

but this bulb is clearly missing
a lot of wavelengths - colors.

Just for reference, here's the spectrum
from a green laser pointer.

Not really a spectrum, since
this is monochromatic light.
It's only green.
Now, back to the flourescent bulb.

Do you see that?
The yellow completely disappears.

The remaining spectrum is what
our eyes see as light blue.

With the incandescent light we can tell,
that some green is also absorbed

but the remaining broader spectrum is
what our eyes see as violet or lavender.

But what is causing this absorption
of colors in the vase?

Well, the vase is made of neodymium glass,
often called Alexandrit glass.

It contains neodymium oxide,
which I have a sample of here.

The neodymium metal ions in this
are absorbing the yellow light.

It's not a strong effect in opaque powder form,
but hopefully you can see it.

Now, if neodymium ions absorb all yellow light,
what happens if we shine a yellow light on it?

insect-repelling light, which is very yellow.

For more brightness, it is also emitting red + green,
which looks yellow to us when mixed.
I have already shown this with laser beams.

Yellow can therefore go through this vase as a

The final question is:
What happens to the absorbed light?
Does it just disappear?

No. Most likely we are seeing
an effect of fluorescence.

We usually think of fluorescence as something shiny,
because we can see the emission part of fluorescence.

The fluorescent beads absorb the invisible,
ultraviolet light and emit visible light.

We can't see the invisible light being absorbed
but we certainly can see the visible light being emitted.

With the neodymium glass we are
seeing the absorption part in stead.

The visible light is absorbed and
emitted as invisible, infrared light.

Since we can't see infrared light, we only notice
the absorption part of this fluorescence.
I wish I had a USB spectrometer.
